data.title: Oscar Bait 2023-2024
data.meta_description: And I'm not sure what that coda was all about.
data.text:
And I'm not sure what that coda was all about.

It’s highlighting that the federal government, having taken years to initially investigate, did an awful job and were satisfied with a couple of convictions. The corruption and abuse was widespread but barely tackled. Then Hoover/the FBI used the meagre results to promote themselves in a radio series and The FBI Story (1959).

Rather than using title cards, it’s shown as a production that actually happened. That the story was used to entertain, and the entertainment that true crime can give unaffected audiences. And Scorsese puts himself in there at the end, maybe because he’s concerned about his complicity within the media ecosystem, worried about people who see something to admire in the awful protagonists he’s made films about.

And he reads the final line, saying the Osage murders weren’t even mentioned in Mollie’s obituary. They were swept under the carpet as so much of the United States’ genocide of their indigenous population has been.

Gotham Award Nominees 2023

These don't really matter in the grand scheme of things but this year with actors on strike and unable to campaign getting early nominations and momentum could prove important.

Lots of contenders showing up here but some very odd snubs. Loving the A Thousand and One attention. My favourite film of the year. Would be overjoyed if Teyana gained some traction.

Yeah I got the message - it was the artistic 'vehicle' that was used to convey that message (and the cameo) that came out of the blue for me and took me out of the story.

As I understand it, the book goes into much more detail about how the Osage murders played a part in establishing the FBI than the film. So I'm intrigued to read that, as well as watch the film again on Apple TV - where I think it may work better with access to a pause button.

Felt like a total cop out to me. Marty comes on at the end to gaslight us into believing it was Molly's story all along rather than actually tell the story from a woman's perspective in the first place. God forbid.

Molly looms over the entire film for me. Ultimately her lack of available perspective is there because how could she? A Native American woman in the 1920s, without control of her own finances due to the guardian system (her original being linked to the KKK and then it being Ernest), chronically ill and poisoned. Adding her going to Washington herself was a key break from history but ultimately the story is much about the agency she is denied.

I don't think the heartbreaking reality of her situation would be fixed with some grand speech or Oscar moment.

Instead be get 3 1/2 hours of Leo's grand speeches and Oscar moments. The trip to Washington is a case in point. You could make a whole film about just that story instead it's done away with in a quick montage whereas every moment of her awful husband's story is told in detail. Marty chose to tell the story of a Native woman through the eyes of a white man. Quelle surprise.

Priscilla was a mixed bag for me. It’s very atypical Sofia at its best and at its most stagnant.

However, Caitlin Spaeny is such a revelation as Priscilla. She is the strongest part of this and loved her in the role. Much like many of Coppola’s female protagonists, we view Priscilla through a myopic lens. It feels like we see Priscilla’s entire life up to marrying Elvis in the blink of an eye and then she’s trapped in Graceland, just trying to play with her dog without hundreds of pleebs screaming/staring at her through the gates. Spaeny manages to break through these barriers and give a warm, deeply layered performance.

I did have one major gripe that I never thought I’d see in a film made my Sofia: Elvis being painted as a victim. The film goes into overdrive trying to make us feel bad for Elvis and his overnight fame. The pedophilic nature of his age gap with Priscilla is painted as “oh he’s this young man thrust into jumonstrous fame, he couldn’t help who he fell in love with.” A little gross.

I really didn’t get that from the film. He’s already a massive international star by the time Priscilla meets him. We don’t witness his rise and we only have brief references to Colonel Tom Parker, while Elvis (2022) spends far more time portraying Elvis as Parker’s victim.

You see the typical grooming talk, “She’s much more mature than her age” and his lies to her from an early stage. He disappears for a year then comes back with extreme attention sweeping her back into his world. They were limited by it being an adaptation of Priscilla’s book, and her still in her 70s having affection for him.

We hear his point of view as he’s manipulating Priscilla but I never took the film’s viewpoint to ever be that what he’s saying is truthful. Because at the same time he’s controlling her and her appearance and taking away all agency from her.
